reason: Induced seismicity observed in Hellisheiði is found to be highly temperature dependent. Thermal stressing is significantly promoted by cooling-induced fracture permeability enhancement, controlling the stability conditions of the fractures. The spatial and temporal evolution of the sesimic events can only be numerically reproduced by considering a significant contribution of thermal permeability enhancement. Calibration of numerical models against field injectivity data shows that injectivity is governed by the injected fluid temperature. The colder the injected fluid, the higher the injectivity.

Goebel et al. (2015)

reason: Pore pressure build up by water injection into 8 wells and direct hydraulic connection with the basement has potentially triggered the earthquake. Regional induced earthquake in the Delaware Basin are linked with wastewater injection in the shallower Delaware sandstone layer. The Mentone sequence is an example of local earthquakes in this region modulated by direct hydraulic connection between the basement and the Ellenburger carbonates.
comment: Two HF jobs at distances of 2.4 and 2.9 km from the M5 earthquakes have been respectively completed 48 and 102 days before this earthquake. The possible link between the HF jobs and the earthquake requires complementary studies.
data_sources: Skoumal et al. (2020), Tung et al. (2020), Tung et al. (2021), Zhai et al. (2021)
McGarr (2014), Nicholson et al. (1988)
Ake et al. (2005), Foxall et al. (2017)

reason: Both pore pressure diffusion and poroelastic stresses have probably triggered the earthquakes. Another possible mechanism can be the weigth of injected fluid into the reservoir applying stress on the underlying basement (Johann and Shapiro, 2020). Just like 2011 M5.7 Prague earthquake, static stress transfer by a foreshock (M3.7) could contribute to triggering the main shock (Chen et al., 2017).
data_sources: Barbour et al. (2017), Chen et al. (2017), Johann and Shapiro (2020), Manga et al. (2016), McGarr and Barbour (2017), Walsh III & Zoback (2016), Yeck et al. (2017), Yu (2017), Zhai et al. (2019)

reason: Pore pressure diffusion, poroelastic stresses and statis weight of injected fluid (the reservoir was initially underpressured) are contributing mechanisms of induced seismicitiy in the underlying basement. The main shock could have triggered by static stress transfer from a M5.0 foreshock (Sumy et al., 2014)
data_sources: Chen et al. (2017), Johann and Shapiro (2020), Keranen et al. (2013), McGarr and Barbour (2017), McMahon et al. (2017), Norbeck & Horne (2016), Sumy et al. (2014), Sun & Hartzell (2014), Zhai et al. (2019)
Barnhart et al. (2014), Nakai et al. (2017), Rubenstein et al. (2012), Rubinstein et al. (2014)

reason: Direct pore pressure transmission from the injection reservoir to the basement through a high-permeability fault (D=0.01 m2/s): pore pressure increase of 0.08 MPa in the seismicity zone, broadly consistent in timing with the occurence of a dominant seismic sequence
comment: The earthquake has been nucleated within the basement.
data_sources: Barnhart et al. (2014), Nakai et al. (2017), Rubenstein et al. (2012), Rubenstein et al. (2014)

comment: Water disposal near former large oil fields
data_sources: Goebel et al. (2015), Goebel et al. (2016), Zielke et al. (2012)
